verses.text: Now in the church at Antioch there were prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.
verses.comment: Antioch became an early center of Christian leadership. Note the diversity in the list—suggests the universality of the Church. Saul (later Paul) is introduced among notable teachers and prophets.

verses.text: While they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, 'Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them.'
verses.comment: Worship and fasting in communal setting—early liturgical practice. Direct guidance by the Holy Spirit shows divine initiative in ministry appointments.

verses.text: Then, after fasting and praying, they laid hands on them and sent them off.
verses.comment: Laying on of hands, with prayer and fasting, reflects the sacramental nature of mission and apostolic succession, visibly confirming God’s call.

verses.text: Being sent out by the Holy Spirit, they went down to Seleucia, and from there they sailed to Cyprus.
verses.comment: The Spirit directs missionary outreach, showing reliance on divine guidance over merely human planning.

verses.text: Arriving at Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews. John was with them as their helper.
verses.comment: Preaching in synagogues shows priority to the Jewish people, fulfilling the 'to the Jew first' principle of salvation history (Rom 1:16).

verses.text: When they had traveled through the whole island as far as Paphos, they found a certain magician, a false prophet named Bar-Jesus.
verses.comment: Interaction with false prophets highlights early Church’s struggle against spiritual deception.

verses.text: He was with the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. The proconsul summoned Barnabas and Saul and sought to hear the word of God.
verses.comment: Gentiles in positions of power show openness to the gospel and anticipate later widespread Gentile conversion.

verses.text: But Elymas the magician—for that is the meaning of his name—opposed them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the faith.
verses.comment: Spiritual resistance to the gospel is manifested here; note the connection between sorcery and opposition to truth.

verses.text: But Saul, also known as Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, stared straight at him
verses.comment: Paul is introduced under his Roman name, signifying his mission to the Gentiles. Being filled with the Spirit precedes authoritative action.

verses.text: and said, 'You son of the devil, enemy of all righteousness, full of deceit and fraud, will you not stop twisting the straight paths of the Lord?'
verses.comment: Strong condemnation is reserved for those who actively corrupt the message of salvation.

verses.text: 'Now, look, the hand of the Lord is upon you, and you will be blind, unable to see the sun for a time.' Immediately, darkness and blindness fell on him, and he went around seeking someone to lead him by the hand.
verses.comment: Paul’s judgment mirrors his own previous blindness (Acts 9:8). God uses both spiritual and physical means to accomplish His purposes.

verses.text: Then the proconsul, seeing what had happened, believed, astonished at the teaching of the Lord.
verses.comment: Signs and wonders confirm the apostolic message, serving as divine validation for the truth of the gospel.

verses.text: Now Paul and his companions set sail from Paphos and came to Perga in Pamphylia. John left them and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: John Mark’s departure will later result in division but also eventual reconciliation, illustrating forgiveness and unity as key themes for believers.

verses.text: But they went on from Perga and came to Antioch in Pisidia. On the Sabbath day they went into the synagogue and sat down.
verses.comment: Paul’s pattern of first preaching in synagogues reveals the continuity of God’s plan with the Old Covenant.

verses.text: After the reading from the Law and the Prophets, the leaders of the synagogue sent word to them, saying, 'Brothers, if you have any word of encouragement for the people, speak.'
verses.comment: Reading scripture in liturgical assembly is a foundational practice for the Christian faith, pointing to the role of tradition and teaching.

verses.text: So Paul stood up, made a gesture with his hand and said, 'Men of Israel, and you who fear God, listen.'
verses.comment: Paul addresses both Jews and Gentile God-fearers, reflecting an inclusive invitation to salvation.

verses.text: 'The God of this people Israel chose our fathers, exalted the people during their stay in Egypt, and with an uplifted arm He led them out from it.'
verses.comment: Paul roots the gospel in God’s election and salvation history, emphasizing continuity from Abraham to Moses.

verses.text: 'And for about forty years He put up with them in the wilderness.'
verses.comment: Paul’s reference to Israel’s stubbornness underlines God’s patience and providential care.

verses.text: 'And after destroying seven nations in the land of Canaan, He gave their land as an inheritance to His people.'
verses.comment: God’s provision of the promised land exemplifies fulfillment of covenant promises.

verses.text: 'All this took about four hundred and fifty years. After this He gave them judges until Samuel the prophet.'
verses.comment: Review of the historical timeline emphasizes God’s long-term work of salvation.

verses.text: 'Then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.'
verses.comment: Israel’s desire for a king and God’s granting of Saul sets up the need for a righteous king—foreshadowing Christ.

verses.text: 'After removing him, He raised up David to be their king, to whom He testified and said: 'I have found in David the son of Jesse a man after My own heart, who will do all My will.''
verses.comment: David as a type of Christ—the true King—fulfills God’s will perfectly (see Christological fulfillment in Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: 'From this man’s descendants God has brought to Israel a Savior, Jesus, as He promised.'
verses.comment: Direct connection: Jesus is the fulfillment of prophecy as the Savior descended from David (see Rom 1:3-4).

verses.text: 'Before His coming, John preached a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.'
verses.comment: John’s preparatory ministry recalls the need for repentance and purification before the coming of the Messiah.

verses.text: 'As John was finishing his course, he said, ‘Who do you suppose I am? I am not He. But behold, after me comes One whose sandals I am not worthy to untie.’'
verses.comment: John the Baptist points beyond himself to Jesus, recognizing his own subordinate role—a model for humility in ministry.

verses.text: 'Brothers, sons of the family of Abraham, and those among you who fear God, to us the message of this salvation has been sent.'
verses.comment: Salvation is offered to both Jews and Gentiles who fear God, emphasizing the universality of grace.

verses.text: 'For those residing in Jerusalem and their rulers, because they did not recognize Him nor the voices of the prophets that are read every Sabbath, fulfilled those words by condemning Him.'
verses.comment: Rejection and crucifixion of Jesus fulfill the very Scriptures read in the synagogues, illustrating the depth of prophetic fulfillment.

verses.text: 'Though they found no cause for death in Him, they asked Pilate to put Him to death.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ innocence fulfills messianic prophecy (Isa 53:9), exposing the unjust nature of His death.

verses.text: 'When they had carried out all that was written about Him, they took Him down from the tree and laid Him in a tomb.'
verses.comment: Reference to 'the tree' underscores the curse Jesus bore (Gal 3:13) and the fulfillment of Old Testament burial prophecy.

verses.text: 'But God raised Him from the dead.'
verses.comment: Central proclamation: resurrection is the heart of the Christian faith. God’s power is victorious over death.

verses.text: 'He was seen for many days by those who came up with Him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are now His witnesses to the people.'
verses.comment: Eyewitness testimony grounds the resurrection as a historical reality, with chosen witnesses confirming divine revelation.

verses.text: 'And we bring you good news of that promise made to the fathers,'
verses.comment: Good news (euangelion) is the fulfillment of God’s covenant to Abraham and David.

verses.text: 'God has fulfilled this for us, their children, by raising Jesus; as it is also written in the second Psalm: ‘You are My Son, today I have begotten You.’'
verses.comment: Psalm 2:7 is quoted, showing Christ’s divine Sonship—the fulfillment of messianic prophecy with high christological significance.

verses.text: 'And regarding that He raised Him from the dead, no longer to return to corruption, He has spoken: ‘I will give you the holy and sure blessings of David.’'
verses.comment: Christ’s resurrection is a participation in divine life—never to return to decay—affirming the eternal kingly promises to David.

verses.text: 'Therefore He also says in another Psalm: ‘You will not let Your Holy One see decay.’'
verses.comment: Direct Messianic prophecy; early Christians saw Psalm 16 as speaking of Jesus’ resurrection—He alone never saw corruption.

verses.text: 'For David, after serving God’s purpose in his own generation, fell asleep, was buried with his fathers, and saw corruption.'
verses.comment: David’s death and decay contrast with the everlasting life given through Christ—pointing to Christ alone as the eternal King.

verses.text: 'But the One whom God raised up did not see corruption.'
verses.comment: Unique resurrection—Jesus’ body did not experience decay, a sign of new creation and the glorified humanity.

verses.text: 'Therefore, let it be known to you, brothers, that through this Man forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you.'
verses.comment: Forgiveness of sins—the central gift of Jesus—announced publicly. This sets up the sacramental context for true reconciliation with God.

verses.text: 'And by Him everyone who believes is justified from all things from which you could not be justified by the law of Moses.'
verses.comment: Justification by faith in Christ surpasses Mosaic Law, directing focus on grace, faith, and transformation—a union with God beyond mere legal observance.

verses.text: 'Beware, therefore, so that what is spoken in the prophets may not come upon you:'
verses.comment: Paul warns that prophecy can serve as both blessing and warning; fulfillment depends on response to God’s message.

verses.text: '‘Look, you scoffers, marvel and perish; for I am doing a work in your days, a work you would never believe, even if someone told you.’'
verses.comment: Quoted from Habakkuk—God’s acts may seem incredible, yet they are accomplished by His will, and require faith-filled acceptance.

verses.text: As they were leaving, the people begged that these things be spoken to them again the next Sabbath.
verses.comment: Eagerness to hear the word signals the Spirit’s drawing power and the necessity of continued catechesis.

verses.text: When the meeting of the synagogue broke up, many Jews and God-fearing converts followed Paul and Barnabas, who, speaking to them, urged them to continue in the grace of God.
verses.comment: Perseverance in grace is encouraged. The focus on 'continuing' means faith is also lived and grown, not only professed.

verses.text: The next Sabbath, almost the whole city gathered to hear the word of the Lord.
verses.comment: The dramatic growth shows both the power of the word and the contagious effect of authentic preaching.

verses.text: But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with jealousy and began to contradict what Paul was saying, insulting him.
verses.comment: Jealousy and opposition arose as the gospel challenged established religious boundaries—indicating transformative potential.

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas spoke out boldly and said, 'It was necessary that the word of God be spoken first to you. But since you reject it and judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, behold, we turn to the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: Paul announces transition to Gentile-focused mission. Still, the offer is to everyone, and historical continuity with God’s people remains integral.

verses.text: For so the Lord has commanded us, saying, 'I have made you a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.'
verses.comment: Isaiah’s prophecy is seen fulfilled—Jesus and His message extend salvation to all nations (see Christ’s commission in Matt 28:19).

verses.text: When the Gentiles heard this, they rejoiced and glorified the word of the Lord, and as many as were destined to eternal life believed.
verses.comment: Divine providence and human response are held together: those 'destined' respond freely and joyfully, showing God’s initiative and grace.

verses.text: And the word of the Lord spread throughout the whole region.
verses.comment: Evangelization and mission are shown as community efforts, not just individual action—emphasizing the ongoing expansion of the apostolic work.

verses.text: But the Jews stirred up the devout women of prominence and the leading men of the city, and incited persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and drove them out of their region.
verses.comment: Persecution often emerges from religious and social authorities when the gospel challenges established power structures.

verses.text: So they shook the dust off their feet against them and went to Iconium.
verses.comment: Shaking off the dust is a prophetic sign of judgment, yet the mission continues elsewhere—demonstrating perseverance and focus in apostolic ministry.

verses.text: And the disciples were continually filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Joy and the fullness of the Spirit are marks of those faithfully living out the faith in community. Note the emphasis on community and the Spirit's continual action.
